prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Effect of Transfer: Proceedings in the Transferee Court

head.headtext: Disposition in the transferee court—Disposition versus remand

para.paratext: Many cases are disposed of (resolved) in the transferee court. As indicated in Chapter 3, the statute contemplates that transfer will be effected for pretrial proceedings only and that the actions will be remanded to the transferor courts for trial.[1] In practice remand has proven the exception rather than the rule in multidistrict litigation.

There are a number of methods whereby multidistrict litigation may be disposed of in the transferee court, thereby obviating remand. These reasons include resolution of the cases on motions, settlement of the cases, transfer of venue to the transferee court for trial, and consolidation of transferred cases with those already pending in the transferee court for trial.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
28 U.S.C.A. § 1407(a). The statute is reprinted in § 3:19. Remand is discussed in Chapter 10.
